questions.question: If Random Search is used on a graph with multiple paths, what is the outcome?

answers.a: It always finds the shortest path.
answers.b: It may find the goal but not necessarily the shortest path.
answers.c: It explores all nodes before reaching the goal.
answers.d: It guarantees failure in large graphs.

questions.question: Suppose Random Search is applied to find a path from A to D. If the random choices are A → B → E (dead-end), what is the algorithm likely to do next?

answers.c: Randomly restart or choose another unexplored path.
answers.d: Wait until user gives another input.

questions.question: Why does Random Search not guarantee success in graph traversal?

answers.a: Because it does not use heuristics or structured exploration.
answers.b: Because it explores all possible paths before stopping.
answers.c: Because it requires a cost function to work.
answers.d: Because it is slower than BFS or DFS.

questions.question: In optimization problems, Random Search is useful when:

answers.a: The search space is small and deterministic.
answers.b: The search space is large, and systematic exploration is infeasible.
answers.c: An exact optimal solution is always needed.

questions.question: Which scenario best illustrates the randomness of Random Search?

answers.a: Always producing the same path when run multiple times.
answers.b: Producing different paths on different runs, sometimes failing, sometimes succeeding.
answers.c: Always finding the shortest path regardless of graph size.
answers.d: Stopping only after exploring all nodes.
